Even if the zombies aren't braindead useless corpses that some people are saying, they obviously wouldn't function normally, since the virus is still messimg with their brain and it's trying to fight against it. They would get stressed very quickly and may have a spike in adrenaline but that's it. They would start to feel tired if they don't get enough food, even if they eat random animals they might get poisoned. The elements would also wear them down, their health would decrease with time. Even if it's a rabies like thing that trasmits by a bite, 1st that would be a open wound on the new zombie, accelerating decomposition and infection and 2nd the zombie who bit didn't feed itself much right? Like either we have thousands of starving zombies that don't eat much or we have a few zombies that actually eat people. Also not everyone is in the best fit in the first place, old people, unhealthy people would have an ever worse time. So basically, in a while the number of actual scary zombies would decrease, most would have died either killed or by starving/injures etc.

The scariest part really is the virus itself. If it somehow is spread by air (saliva droplets?), then yes that would be very scary. ESPECIALLY if the first symptoms took a long time to appear so we could have a very high initial number of them, including scientists and medics and stuff. But that's if a virus like that could appear in the first place. Science wins again: hopefully microbiologists will be tracking these potential viruses to see if one could actually achieve that, and then study the precautions to not get people contaminated and extermine it (i know that's a very hard task). And like i don't think it's possible that someone in an instant becomes full on zombie, they would probably feel stuff beforehand and unless the disease can disguise itself as something else, the doctor this person sees will notice something strange and investigations begin. Lockdown would happen on this person's town and they would track their habits/locations and notify the government for other actions. Other tool for us would be communication.: hopefully governments would work together and notify everyone, this would be a local event at first to so we would do our best to make everyone STAY HOME. anyways i really hope thos never happens or if it does, it won't be so brutal. The virus would not be biological (biological viruses cannot animate dead people), it would be technological, and would most likely not be from Earth. Here is how it would work to produce exactly what one sees depicted in movies and television series about the zombie apocalypse:

1. Extraterrestrials drop off nanotechnology virus in atmosphere, perhaps for sick entertainment (we cannot assume extraterrestrials have empathy or concern for humans) or to cull the heard, even to save resources they figure they might need in the future.
2. The nano-virus reproduces and infects everyone on Earth.3.
3. The nano-virus then creates networks in the bodies and brains of most people who are infected, and they die from the process. It also builds networks in the eyes, nose, and ears for crude sensory input, and the virus invades the brain to build the control network on the microscopic level. The networks are not visible to the naked eye, if one were to cut open a zombie.
4. The dead are reanimated with microscopic nanobot fibers, built and embedded in the flesh, that act like muscle fibers to animate the corpse, and the apocalypse takes over the Earth extremely quickly, as everyone is already infected. The government and military also turn, so there are no agencies to save the living from the apocalypse.
5. The nano-virus maintains the dead by keeping the flesh and blood from drying out and going stiff, and puts antifreeze into dead flesh in winter to keep the dead from freezing solid. The virus does minimal repair to the rotting flesh so zombies will last indefinitely.
6. Damaging the brain damages the control network built into the brain, so the zombie goes down, but harming the rest of the body does not stop it.
7. Being bitten activates the virus, and dying of any cause will also do so.

I don't think you should dismiss "undead" zombies so quickly. There are examples of this occurring in nature. Not a long dead guy coming back to life, but a fungus or creature that enters our brain, "kills us", and controls our actions to spread itself among other humans before our bodies die, similar to how O. unilateralis kills ants. Look no further than BSE/CJD (Which are prion diseases) and also fits, since prion diseases are spread by eating brain tissue and can't be destroyed through cooking.

A lot of existing diseases like Trichinosis (spread through Pork and Rats) are also transmissible due to animals eating the remains of other animals. Toxoplasma gondii (typically spread from cat feces) causes schizophrenia.

So the most plausible cause of "zombie" behavior in humans would be CJD, those bitten would simply die, not become zombies. CJD also doesn't act very quickly (taking a few years before dementia takes hold.) But what would most likly cause a "zombie outbreak" itself would be a mutation of Toxoplasma gondii that jumps from cats/rats to other animals.

Why are people saying zombies will "die in a week because of starvation or medical reasons?" People are literally making their own concept of what zombies actually are. If we follow the mainstream idea of what a zombie is, it would be a virus that infects healthy hosts, so the zombies would not attack each other. If "zombies" existed, they wouldn't be like you'd expect. First off, they'd most likely attack each other unless a mutation in the virus strand occurred, or evolution over a course of time. Also, even if they didn't attack each other, they won't exactly be easy to kill. They aren't going to be slow. Most likely, the zombies will probably be running at you. Don't think about zombies shambling towards your door, no. Think about zombies smashing through your window and rushing towards you. That's most likely how they'd be, as there are already viruses and drugs that induce such behavior. Rather than eating you, it will probably just beat you to death.

I know zombies are fake, but hypothetically speaking, if a lone zombie (virus or fungus infected, not reborn) bites you, will it just let you go and leave you, knowing you are going to turn, thus completing its mission? Or will it outright kill / eat you? It seems like an obvious question, but let's think. If zombies in all the movies managed to overthrow powerful 1st world governments and most of the world, they had to have some intelligence. If they outright ate their victims, their virus wouldn't spread unless they ignored or left at least 80% of the corpse (including the brain, and all vital organs and necessities). This means that they'd have to rely on their victim escaping to spread their infection, which isn't exactly effective. Furthermore, most people, once bitten, would probably commit suicide, right?
BUT HEYY, THAT'S JUST A THEORY, A GAME THEORY!

||| The Flaws of A Zombie Apocalypse |||

1. Zombies would attack other zombies

2. Wouldn't zombies go after things like ACTUAL food instead of humans?

3. If we are talking about a zombie that's still "alive", the zombie would die from lack of water in a week MAX

4. For the military technology we have today, zombies shouldn't be a problem.

5. All we need to do is just explode the cities with mass zombies and kill out the herds, and then zombies would be considered as: "just another thing trying to take you down".

6. In a zombie apocalypse, everyone wouldn't be committing suicide, no, nothing like that. People would be training how to crowd control zombies from the military.

7. It would be almost impossible for a virus SO specific to create a zombie

8. If zombies were alive but kinda "dead", maggots would eat them

9. Everyone would get to high places like Denver and just wait for the zombies to die out.

The problem with the disease category of zombie as apposed to the reanimation category is that when the zombie feeds, it is likely to kill its food, meaning that its victim couldn't spread the disease farther. However, on the other hand, the disease described in the video is an olfactory disease, meaning that you would just need to smell zombies and you would get infected. A more evolutionarily successful virus would probably avoid killing their host or giving their host the incentive to kill others, but instead behaive more like the (oral) herpes virus which spreads like wildfire and does pretty much nothing to their host except make their mouths ugly for a little while.

The really scary thing is there ARE parasites, fungi, and viruses that cause zombie-like behavior or cause other radical behavioral changes including changes that may be counter to survival. There is a fungus that infects ants. It forces the ant to climb a blade of grass or other object above the colony. The and then latches onto so she won't fall off. Then she dies and the fungus grows in her body until the ant explodes spreading spores to more ants.
  Mammals can be infected as well. There is a parasite that must use a cat's body for part of it's life cycle. The cat excretes the parasite in it's poop but to reproduce it must get into a cat somehow. The problem is, cats are unlikely to eat anything exposed to cat poop, so the parasite homes to enter the body of a mouse. The mouse then becomes attracted to (rather than repulsed by) the smell of cats. Eventually the mouse gets eaten by a cat.
  The parasite doesn't harm the cat and most cats that go outside are infected. Cats can spread the parasite to humans which are a dead end (cats don't usually eat humans) but it is theorized that the parasite can cause a person to become less risk averse and even to seek out thrills like sky diving.

I can no longer hear about rabies without thinking about a story I saw on a show called "Monsters inside me." In 2003, a lovely young lady by the name of Shannon Reid, age 15, got sick and started seeing double and even triple. These symptoms continued for a couple weeks, gradually getting worse. Her parents took her to the doctor and she was misdiagnosed with migraine headaches. On May 31, she was shopping with her father, Tony Reid, when she suddenly got a startled look in her eye, stood stiff for a moment, then collapsed and started convulsing. Her father caught her and held her head to prevent her from injuring herself. She was taken to the hospital. She was in a coma for two days. On the second day, the medical staff noticed that her vitals were indicating oncoming death. They notified her parents. Her mother, Patti Reid, said, "I can't be there when my child dies." She had to leave the room. On June 2, 2003, Shannon Reid "gave up the fight", to quote the show. Her body was taken to the morgue to find out what it was that killed her. All that had been said was that Shannon had headaches. It wasn't until months later that the Reid's found out that it was rabies that took there daughter. That story shook me to my core and tore my heart out! I was born only about 3 and a half months after Shannon and I remember what I was doing just about the time she died. I used to think rabies was kind of funny, with the foamy mouth and stuff. (Turns out that's greatly exaggerated.) Not any more. Rabies is a very serious and deadly disease. Rest In Peace, Shannon.

I'm obsessed with zombies.They dominate my dreams - both the day and night versions. I'm fascinated by the concept. I'm always planning for the zombie apocalypse; noting key locations that could serve as a good place to hold up for the long term. I always buy a couple of extra bags of rice and pasta, as well as tinned food when I'm shopping. Me, my wife and two kids will hold out in attic till things have "died" down enough for us to make the move to one of my predetermined safe zones. We'll probably eat our dog Shadow on the first day of the outbreak though, as she barks every time someone comes near the front door and it's only a matter of time before she starts attracting the zombies. That will probably mess with the kid's heads a bit, but by the time we've eaten their mother it won't seem like such a big deal. I've got a baseball bat and a hurley stick for protection, which is as good as it gets for now as I live in Ireland and machetes are hard to come by, but I am hoping to pick up some more effective weapons while I search for food and water supplies (always during the day). We live on an island with a reasonably low population and plenty of isolated areas, I think if we were able to secure a large enough area, such as the grounds of a castle, we could grow crops  making sure we have easy access to a natural water supply. Of course we'd probably try to team up with other groups to increase our chances of achieving this. I don't know what happens after this stage as, but I assume the zombies will soon become the least of our worries, as groups of desperate and hungry survivors scour the countryside for food and shelter. Hopefully we will be in a position to defend ourselves and eventually out-live the zombies, assuming that they WILL eventually decay and rot....so as I was saying, I'm a little obsessed with zombies.

Oh my goodness! The lack of zombie knowledge is shocking! 1) Zombies only eat fresh meat, therefore, zombies will never consume each other. 2)  Zombie plague is not a virus or bacteria, it is a fungus that is spread through spores. These spores are deposited when one is bitten. The transformation could take as much as a week. 3) Taking on zombies one at a time is no problem, but if you run into a "herd" of a 20 or more, you're pretty much f**cked! One human with one gun isn't going to be able to handle all of that by themselves. Besides, guns are NOT the best weapon against zombies. Gunfire attracts zombies, as does fire, and in general, any human noises. There are 7 billion people on the planet. If a zombie apocalypse happens it will infect at least 60% of the population. So let's do the math, 4.2 billion zombies vs. 2.8 billion people. On top of that, there are many, many people who don't have the means or methods to fight and survive the apocalypse. So you can cut that 2.8 billion down to about 40%. Let's do the math again... That leaves 1.1 billion people in the world to battle all of these zombies. I'm being quite generous here, as I don't see that there are 1 billion people on the planet who are capable of living in any type of apocalypse scenario, not to mention a zombie apocalypse.

Not sure how to respond to a certain comment, but I'll answer the one about the jump to our modern day zombies from the voodoo doc's as best I can. Originally, the doc's would feed their victims a poison made in part from tree frogs I believe, and a few other nice and deadly on their own ingredients. The result would be that the victim would fall into a coma after experiencing high enough fevers to basically kill off most brain functions. Everyone would assume the victim was dead, and so would bury them. The witch doc then would exhumate them and revive the body, which by this point is basically a shambling mostly dead vegetable, making an ideal slave  that doesnt feel pain and wouldn't fight back. Downside is the limited ability for them to understand instructions, but thats what I've heard about the origin of zombies. Its been a few years so I can't remember where I read it though, sorry. But from that its not much of a stretch to the dead coming back and infecting others. I would imagine being bit would result in some sort of infection...

So I was curious what caused the jump from this ritual involving witch doctors and abduction to the western version of flesh eating zombies who rise from the dead? I was under the impression that you would be discussing agents that could cause a zombie-like state, and while this video was entertaining, I felt it was a bit too generic and that I don't think you delved into examples of such agents that presently exist. For example, the origin of the zombie started as a chemical concoction "witch doctors" provided for people to use against their enemies, which would induce a state of unconsciousness so similar to death that you were buried in a shallow grave; once the subject awoken, they dig themselves out of the ground still suffering from the poisons derived from puffer fish that could be described as zombies. Another example would be prions - a retrovirus that infects other proteins, altering them from their original function ans turning them into more prions, as what happened with Mad Cow Disease. In addition, the video game The Last of Us demonstrated that a tropical fungus, cordyceps, presently accomplish said goal of infecting insects, and for the purpose of the story it was written that they were able to infect humans, which in all honesty isn't too far of a stretch, seeing how Influenza is transmitted across ducks and pigs, so why can't a fungus infect another species? These are merely examples I just came up with, but all the same it was an entertaining video and I love what you put out. Thank you!

Such afflicted individuals would likely be in favor of consuming practically anything, including live human meat. Enraged insatiable hunger with nothing behind the controls is savagery at it's most primal.

Basically resulting in a highly volatile/unstable creature, with no concept of morality, no impulse control, no understanding of who or what it is, with an insatiable hunger that combined with everything else would just fuel an equally insatiable rage. Such a virus would make Rabies look no worse than a bad case of the flu.

Not quite. Rabies only results in unprovoked, irrational aggression in non-human animals and only as a result of other symptoms, and not driven by hunger. Rabies does not in particular promote enraged violent tendencies in an infected individual. This hypothetical "zombie virus" WOULD by targeting specific regions of the brain that moderate and govern our impulses, emotions, memory, our perception of morality, and our level of hunger.

From what he explained, these type of hypothetical zombies could be just as easily killed as a normal human being. So, yes, destruction of the brain or heart would result in death to such a zombie, as it would to a normal human being. So would significant blood loss, asphyxiation, starvation, dehydration, anything that could lead to death to any mortal creature.

Theoretically, 40 MPH. Something with, if we had our joints working fast enough and muscles and balance together, we could run tip toe'd leaned forward, and reach 40MPH. The reason we can't do it is due to the muscle/bones. Humans don't have the type of muscles built like a cheetah. Cheetahs breathe at 150 Breathes per minute. Humans, 60 BPM. They have fibers that have a 'fast twitch' concentration, higher than that of a human. 
So basically, we COULD. The thing is, we aren't built for it.

Why won't you run at your full speed? Because there is a limit to ensure that it doesn't cause damage to your body. The exception is a in case of danger, the adrenaline is released, it will boost your sugar usage and enables you to use your full power (which usually saves your life, but also damages your muscles/bones) and kills the pain.

There is no known limit to how fast humans can run because there is always room for improvement. The reason everyone doesn't run the same speed is because of internal and external factors like air and water quality, how good the food you have is, your stress levels, and how much/often you exersize.

Don't worry. Any virus capable of doing this is too large to be transmitted anyway but bodily fluids. The rabies virus is HUGE, for a virus. It can't be carried by air, and dies on contact with fresh or salt water. Also large viruses multiply extremely slow, so a zombie invasion would be more like a trickle.

The other treatment is called the "Milwaukee Protocol," and is the only even remotely effective treatment for symptomatic rabies. Basically, doctors render you clinically brain dead with drugs, which tricks the virus into leaving your brain cells alone, while they flood your body with massive doses of rabies vaccine and antiviral drugs. It only has a 14% success rate; which is better than the 99% rabies fatality rate. But it can't fix the brain damage you've already had. Most people die anyway.

Not if you're already showing symptoms. There are two treatments, which work at different time frames. The standard treatment for rapid animal bites in post exposure rabies vacciniation: a series of injections of a weakened strain of rabies virus, administered IMMEDIATELY (less than 72 hours) after exposure. This trains your immune system to fight off the active virus you've been exposed to. But after the virus starts to multiply, you're fucked.
